acf.hero_headline: Visit an online doctor for bacterial vaginosis (BV) treatment, diagnosis & prescriptions

tab_content.accordion_title: Can a doctor help treat BV on Maple?
tab_content.accordion_intro: In most cases, a Maple doctor can diagnose BV online by asking about your symptoms. Once you describe your symptoms to the doctor, they will be able to diagnose and prescribe appropriate medication.
tab_content.accordion_content: If the doctor suspects you have a more serious problem, they may suggest you go to a clinic for a thorough in-person physical examination.

tab_content.accordion_title: Can I get a prescription on Maple?
tab_content.accordion_intro: Yes, our physicians can prescribe medications online during your consultation. Once you accept a prescription, you’ll have the option to pick it up from any pharmacy or we’ll deliver it right to your door at no additional cost.
tab_content.accordion_content: You can visit our How it Works page to learn more.

tab_content.accordion_intro:
Bacterial vaginosis (BV) is an inflammation caused by overgrowth of vaginal bacteria.

There is no determined cause for BV, but some activities can increase your risk of infection, like:

  • Frequent douching
  • Inability to produce good lactobacilli bacteria
  • Sexual activity
  • Smoking
tab_content.accordion_content:
To lower your risk of getting BV you should:

  • Avoid douching
  • Clean your genital area with only water
  • Have you and your partner tested for STI’s
  • Use a condom during intercourse
  • Wipe from front to back

tab_content.accordion_title: What are the symptoms of BV?
tab_content.accordion_intro:
The symptoms are minor, or do not show at all. If symptoms do occur, you might notice:

  • Burning feeling when you urinate
  • Fishy vaginal smell that’s stronger after sex
  • Grey, white, or green discharge
tab_content.accordion_content: BV is often confused with yeast infections, but it is a unique condition. Typical symptoms of a yeast infection include general irritation or itching around the vaginal area and thick, white, odourless discharge.

tab_content.accordion_intro:
Many cases of BV tend to go away on their own, and do not require treatment.

You should see a doctor if you are experiencing symptoms of BV, and:

  • You’re pregnant
  • You’ve experienced vaginal infections before, but the colour and consistency of your discharge is different
  • You’ve had multiple sex partners or a new partner
  • Your symptoms continue after treatment
  • You have vaginal discharge that’s new and associated with an odour
  • Avoid sexual activity until your BV is treated
tab_content.accordion_content: When symptoms do occur, antibiotics are typically prescribed.

tab_content.accordion_intro:
